image.altText: A man wearing spectacles, suit and tie sits in an office chair.

items.synopsis: A suspected Ponzi scheme that has ensnared Melbourne racing identities and a senior AFL figure was offering returns of up to 8 per cent before the sudden death of its alleged mastermind last month.

title.children: Deceased Melbourne lawyer under investigation for alleged $100 million mortgage Ponzi scheme

image.altText: soldiers advancing in smoke

items.synopsis: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu says forces have passed the outskirts of Gaza City, while Hezbollah attacks Israeli border positions.

title.children: Israeli troops advance towards Gaza City as Hezbollah attacks in the north

image.altText: Grey skies and clouds in Bundaberg

items.synopsis: While even a 50mm soaking is unlikely to put out the larger blazes, the rain should assist in controlling the future spread of fires while also preventing new ones igniting.

title.children: Major thunderstorm outbreak to deliver much needed rain to Queensland and NSW

image.altText: Shirtless man kneeling on the ground

items.synopsis: The Australian Federal Police says it is aware of the Turkish arrest and acknowledged officials for "undertaking one of the most significant operations" of transnational organised criminals.

title.children: Turkish authorities say they have arrested alleged Australian drug trafficker Hakan Ayik

image.altText: Samah stands in the middle of the protest crowd, wearing a black and white shirt.

items.synopsis: Palestinians living in Australia mourn the death of loved ones in Gaza while dealing with survivor's guilt, while some warn of a looming mental health crisis.

title.children: 'Do you have any news?': What it's like for Australian Palestinians to mourn family in Gaza from afar

image.altText: A woman cries in front of a car.

items.synopsis: Erin Patterson, who cooked a mushroom lunch in late July suspected of resulting in three people's deaths, faces charges including murder and attempted murder.

title.children: Police lay murder charges over mushroom deaths after Erin Patterson arrested

image.altText: A man raising a wine glass while another man walks towards him.

items.synopsis: As Xi Jinping faces a double dip in China's economy and public support wanes in his third term, interactions between Beijing and the West, including Australia and the United States, have become a tool in his efforts to turn things around, writes Bang Xiao.

title.children: Xi calls China 'the great power' but to show his strength he needs a middle power like Australia to come knocking

image.altText: Silhouette of person with short hair standing against a large window with clear expanse.

items.synopsis: Catholic priest and scholar James Alison knows what it feels like to be a scapegoat. He's devoted his life to understanding why we do it.

title.children: Growing up gay and religious, James felt like a scapegoat for others' fear. It took him decades to learn why

image.altText: A small green sphere representing Earth on a law book, a gavel and scales in the background

items.synopsis: Large Australian companies will soon have to disclose climate risks but there are concerns that legal avenues will be closed off to combat greenwashing.

title.children: Concerns temporary ban on misleading climate claims litigation will undermine Australia's emissions goals

image.altText: He wears a big hat and walks through the bush

items.synopsis: When John Watson was bitten by a crocodile, he knew exactly which plant would help his wound. Scientists now think that plant could lead to a powerful pain relief gel.

title.children: How a croc bite, and quick thinking, could make for a world-beating pain relief remedy

image.altText: 李克强告别仪式

items.synopsis: China has lowered the national flag around the country as the "the people's premier" Li Keqiang is cremated.

title.children: China stops to mourn 'people's premier' Li Keqiang

image.altText: A brick wall says Treaty and has handprints above a painted Aboriginal flag.

items.synopsis: Indigenous elder Mick Gooda says the backlash in Queensland after the failure of the Voice referendum has been greater than he expected.

title.children: 'Takes the wind out of you': Mick Gooda says backlash after failed Voice referendum greater than expected

image.altText: A middle-aged man in a suit with grey hair sits on the green chairs of Australia's parliamentary frontbench.

items.synopsis: There's a general recognition Australia is not on track to achieve the government's commitment to have renewables deliver 82 per cent of electricity by 2030. The treasurer wants to change that.

title.children: Jim Chalmers has plenty on his plate — but he's just added another tricky task

image.altText: Anthony Albanese looks solemn in a close-up shot.

items.synopsis: In their strongest comments since the outbreak of the Israel-Gaza war, the prime minister and foreign minister warn Israel to abide by the rules of war, saying Israeli and Palestinian lives matter, and the international community will not tolerate innocent deaths.

title.children: 'Every Palestinian life matters, like every Israeli life matters': Government urges Israel to observe rules of war

image.altText: A scientist holds up a small container of what looks like red clay.

items.synopsis: Scientists at Deakin University discover how to mulch down old clothing into a pigment as part of an going project looking at textile waste solutions.

title.children: This isn't playdough — it's old clothing. And scientists say it could help solve Australia's fashion waste problem

image.altText: An outdoor staircase in a city area ablaze amid buildings

items.synopsis: The Arson Squad is investigating the cause of a bushfire that burnt close to apartments in central Perth near the popular Jacob's Ladder staircase in Kings Park.

title.children: 'I've never seen anything like that': High-rise residents flee central Perth fire

image.altText: Man smashing windows of shopfront

items.synopsis: Staff at a Tasmanian real estate agency were "shaken and upset" after several plate glass windows were smashed by a hammer-wielding man — as new police data shows crime in the state has bounced back after a lull during COVID.

title.children: Office staff shaken by smashing of windows, as Tasmania Police report spike in crime statistics

image.altText: a volunteer firefighter stands among a group of colleagues listening to a briefing. he's wearing a bandana on his head

items.synopsis: Conditions have eased Thursday, but there are still a multitude of bushfire warnings in southern Queensland, where dozens of homes have been lost.

title.children: Focus remains 'protection of life and property' as interstate help arrives to support fire crews in Queensland

image.altText: Courtney Houssos, with brown hair and pearl earrings, next to Damien Tudehope, wearing glasses

items.synopsis: Courtney Houssos was previously responsible for the State Insurance Regulatory Authority, while her husband was a senior lobbyist at the Insurance Council of Australia.

title.children: NSW minister accuses Liberal MP of 'baseless sexist attack' after questions about husband

image.altText: A man dressed as Santa wearing a face mask.

items.synopsis: The Director of Communicable Diseases at NSW Health has warned a COVID wave could peak at Christmas for the third year in a row.

title.children: Another 'COVID Christmas' on the cards thanks to fresh wave, experts warn

image.altText: A firefighter uses a hose to battle a blaze

items.synopsis: Residents say the location and ignition of bushfires burning near their properties are suspicious, leaving them "stressed" and "frustrated".

title.children: Fire-weary communities 'on edge' as police, RFS investigate if they were deliberately lit

image.altText: A young boy and man kneel on cushions in front of a small shrine.

items.synopsis: Kazuhiro Suzuki is Japan's ambassador to Australia. He is also the son of a trained kamikaze pilot. His family history tells the story of Japan's ruinous embrace of empire, and its transformation in the decades since.

title.children: Ambassador Suzuki carries the weight of his father's past as a kamikaze pilot. He says it tells us about Japan and Australia today

image.altText: A picturesque view of a beach filled with colourful beachgoers.

items.synopsis: What began as a COVID-induced move to the regions doesn't appear to be going away, with city-to-region movement still sitting 11.7 per cent above the pre-COVID average.

title.children: Millennials are still moving out of the cities into the regions, long after pandemic restrictions were lifted

image.altText: A woman stands at a lectern holding an award.

items.synopsis: Mechelle Turvey, whose son Cassius was killed in October 2022, is recognised for her advocacy work to prevent violence and in training police officers to show empathy when dealing with victims of crime.

title.children: Mechelle Turvey announced as WA Australian of the Year

image.altText: A middle aged man with short greying hair stands in front of a backdrop displaying the Australian Parliament House flagpole.

items.synopsis: The treasurer admits that Australia is on track to fall short of its climate targets without more money invested, quicker construction of renewables projects, and better regulation.

title.children: Treasurer Jim Chalmers concedes Australia risks missing its climate targets

image.altText: a volunteer life saver looks out over coogee beach on a hot sydney day

items.synopsis: Giant eddy currents in the sea spread heat. But if trapped in place, they can cause marine heatwaves deadly to sea life. And there's a big one shaping up off Sydney right now.

title.children: A monster eddy current is spinning into existence off the coast of Sydney — and it could be trouble

items.synopsis: Members of an international motorcycle club have been arrested in a coordinated police raid across Cairns in a bid to crack down on emerging crime syndicates.

title.children: Bikie club colours, cash, drugs and weapons confiscated in police crackdown on nascent Cairns group

image.altText: An Australian batsman lets his bat drop to the ground in disappointment after being dismissed in a match.

items.synopsis: Australia suffers another blow ahead of their Cricket World Cup clash against England in Ahmedabad, with Mitch Marsh leaving the Aussie camp for personal reasons.

title.children: Mitch Marsh leaves Cricket World Cup for personal reasons

image.altText: Danny and Michael sitting down looking down at a screen

items.synopsis: Screen Australia has released its latest Drama Report, which shows in part how Australian creators are reaching tens of millions of people around the world by tapping into audiences who have an appetite for content not being picked up on mainstream channels.

title.children: 'It's where the most viewers are': Australian content reaching tens of millions around the world

image.altText: Logo of Royal Brisbane and Women's Hospital

items.synopsis: A man has been seriously injured and three other people have been taken to hospital after a dog attack north of Brisbane.

title.children: Four people taken to hospital after dog attack in Morayfield, north of Brisbane

image.altText: Jason De Ieso was murdered in late 2012

items.synopsis: Jason De Ieso was shot dead at his crash repair business in Adelaide's northern suburbs in 2012, with police and prosecutors arguing he was the accidental victim of a feud between rival bikie gangs.

title.children: Six of seven men found guilty of murder of Jason De Ieso file notice to appeal convictions

image.altText: A dirty bathroom with a sink and toilet

items.synopsis: Slater and Gordon has announced it is investigating a possible class action into "substandard" public housing conditions of remote Aboriginal tenants across the state.

title.children: Law firm flags class action on WA remote housing after landmark High Court decision

image.altText: A gas platform in the Timor Sea.

items.synopsis: An emergency injunction granted to a Tiwi Islands traditional owner by the Federal Court has halted construction of the project's underwater gas export pipeline for several weeks.

title.children: Santos ordered to pause construction on $5.6b Barossa project, hours before works due to start

image.altText: entrance to shopping stor with Kmart signage and customers walking and with trolleys by customer service desk

items.synopsis: Australian retailer Kmart has paid a $1.3 million fine for having sent more than 200,000 marketing emails to people who had already unsubscribed.

title.children: Kmart slapped with $1.3 million fine for sending marketing emails to customers who opted out

image.altText: Celine Dion smiles at Montreal Canadiens head coach Martin St-Louis

items.synopsis: The Canadian singer was seen at an ice hockey game on Monday night, with fans happy to see the star joking and laughing after she revealed her rare neurological illness.

title.children: Smiling Celine Dion makes rare public appearance almost a year after revealing stiff person syndrome diagnosis
